item.title: Ladybird Books
item.dc:creator: boutje777
item.description: Ladybird Books is a London-based publishing company, trading as a stand-alone imprint within the Penguin Group of companies. The Ladybird imprint publishes mass-market children’s books. It is an imprint of Penguin Random House, a subsidiary of German media conglomerate Bertelsmann. The company traces its origins to 1867, when Henry Wills opened a bookshop in Loughborough, […]
item.content:encoded:
Ladybird Books is a London-based publishing company, trading as a stand-alone imprint within the Penguin Group of companies. The Ladybird imprint publishes mass-market children’s books.

It is an imprint of Penguin Random House, a subsidiary of German media conglomerate Bertelsmann.

The company traces its origins to 1867, when Henry Wills opened a bookshop in Loughborough, Leicestershire. Within a decade he progressed to printing and publishing guidebooks and street directories. He was joined by William Hepworth in 1904, and the company traded as Wills & Hepworth.

The pocket-sized hardback Ladybird measured roughly four-and-a-half by seven inches (11.5 cm by 18 cm). Early books used a standard 56-page format, chosen because a complete book could be printed on one large standard sheet of paper, a quad crown, 40 inches by 30 inches, which was then folded and cut to size without waste paper. It was an economical way of producing books, enabling the books to be retailed at a low price which, for almost thirty years, remained at two shillings and sixpence (12.5p).

The first book in the line, Bunnikin’s Picnic Party: a story in verse for children with illustrations in colour, was produced in 1940. The book featured stories in verse written by W. Perring, accompanied by full-colour illustrations by A. J. (Angusine Jeanne) MacGregor. The appeal of Bunnikin, Downy Duckling and other animal characters made the book an instant success. Later series included nature books (series 536, some illustrated by, for example, Charles Tunnicliffe and Allen W. Seaby) and a host of non-fiction books, including hobbies and interests, history (L du Garde Peach wrote very many of these) and travel.

Ladybird began publishing books in other formats in 1980. Most of the remaining titles in the classic format were withdrawn in 1999 when their printing facility in Loughborough closed.

Ladybird – A History of Britain The Saxons and the Normans
Ladybird – History of our Bible
Ladybird – Story of our Churches and Cathedrals

item.title: Story Of Pop
item.dc:creator: boutje777
item.description: The magazines covered aspects of pop and rock from the early origins, through the rock and roll explosion of the 1950s, Merseybeat and psychedelia in the 60s through to glam rock in the 70s; in a roughly chronological order. All with lots of photos and illustrations. The magazine was originally intended to be of 40 […]
item.content:encoded:
The magazines covered aspects of pop and rock from the early origins, through the rock and roll explosion of the 1950s, Merseybeat and psychedelia in the 60s through to glam rock in the 70s; in a roughly chronological order. All with lots of photos and illustrations.

The magazine was originally intended to be of 40 issues, but due to popularity it was extended with a further 13 special edition magazines also issued.

item.title: Ompa-Pa
item.dc:creator: boutje777
item.description: Publisher: Egmont/Methuen Publication Dates: 1977 – 1978 Number of Issues Published: 5 (#1 – #5) Color: colour Dimensions: magazine-size Binding: softcover; squarebound Ompa-pa the Redskin is a comics series created by comics artist Albert Uderzo and comics author Ren Goscinny, best known as the creators of Asterix. The series first appeared in the weekly Tintin […]
item.content:encoded:
Publisher: Egmont/Methuen
Publication Dates: 1977 – 1978
Number of Issues Published: 5 (#1 – #5)
Color: colour
Dimensions: magazine-size
Binding: softcover; squarebound

Ompa-pa the Redskin is a comics series created by comics artist Albert Uderzo and comics author Ren Goscinny, best known as the creators of Asterix. The series first appeared in the weekly Tintin magazine in 1958 though it remained serialised for a relatively short time, ending in 1962. The stories were published in book form by Lombard and Dargaud starting in 1961. In 1995, the series was reissued by Albert Uderzo’s own publishing house, Les ditions Albert-Ren.

The series features the adventures of Ompa-pa (Oumpah-pah in French the name referring to a waltz), a Native American of the Flatfeet tribe, and his friend, the French officer Hubert Brussels Sprout (Hubert de la Pte Feuillete in French, which translates as Hubert of Puff Pastry), whom Ompa-pa calls Two-scalp, a reference to his wig.[1]

The series is set in the 18th century during the age of French colonization in America. Ompa-pa is strong and quick, and loves to eat pemmican. He is an honest and trustworthy brave whose simple heroism is comparable to that of the more famous Asterix, whom Uderzo and Goscinny later created. Hubert Brussels Sprout, whom the Flatfeet initially hold as a prisoner, subsequently serves as a mediator between the Europeans and the Native Americans, and is also an ally against the tribe known as the Sockitoomee, the sworn enemies of the Flatfeet.

When Brussels Sprout introduces Ompa-pa as his brother, his commanding officer remarks: “When madam the Marquise your mother hears about this…”

The character Ompa-pa makes a cameo appearance in the 1976 Asterix film The Twelve Tasks of Asterix, though this story is set in pre-Columbian America.

Ompa-Pa 01-05

Download

item.title: Scotland’s Story
item.dc:creator: boutje777
item.description: Scotland’s Story was published in 1999, a 40 issue magazine series that traced the complete history of Scotland from it’s geological beginnings right up to the millennium, and was beautifully illustrated with many rare photographs and illustrations. As well as chronologically following the main history of this great nation, it was also packed with extra […]
item.content:encoded:
Scotland’s Story was published in 1999, a 40 issue magazine series that traced the complete history of Scotland from it’s geological beginnings right up to the millennium, and was beautifully illustrated with many rare photographs and illustrations. As well as chronologically following the main history of this great nation, it was also packed with extra features, such as Scottish ghost stories, myths and legends, famous Scots in science, literature and the arts, sporting heroes, the Scottish Regiments (Black Watch, Highland Light Infantry, Scot’s Guards, etc, etc).

Volume One – 3 billion BC to 1503: How Scotland was Formed; Fossils and Dinosaurs; Early Scots Settlers; Skara Brae and the Stone Circle Builders; the Picts; the Romans in Scotland; the Coming of Christianity; Scotland in the Dark Ages; the Vikings; Columba; King MacAlpin; Stone of Destiny; Constantine; Cross of St.Andrews; the Real MacBeth; the Middle Ages; King Malcolm and Margaret; King David; Malcolm IV; William I; the Great Cathedrals; the Normans; King of the Isles; Rise of the Clans; Orkneyinga Saga; Alexander II & III; Wars of Independence; William Wallace; Stirling Bridge; Robert the Bruce; Bannockburn; Declaration of Arbroath; David II; Robert II & Robert III; Wolf of Badenoch; the Plague.

Volume Two – 1406 to 1688: Albany Regency; James I; Auld Alliance; Lord of the Isles; Border Reivers; James II; the Douglases; Common Law; Life in the Burghs; James III; Education; Scottish Palaces; the Renaissance; Elphinstone; James IV; Flodden; Scotland at Sea; James V; Printing in Scotland; the Church; the Rough Wooing; Commerce; the Reformation; John Knox; Punishment; Culture; Mary Queen of Scots; Early Maps; the Armada; Story of Dundee; James VI; Union of the Crowns; the Covenant and Covenanters; the Highlands; Rosslyn Chapel; Montrose; the Witch Hunts; Preaching and Piping; Scots Abroad; Cromwell’s Scotland; the Restoration; Soldiers of Fortune; Nova Scotia; the Killing Times; James VII; the Brahan Seer.

Volume Three – 1658 to 1800: the Glorious Revolution and William of Orange; the Jacobites; Killiecrankie; the Campbells; Claverhouse; Glencoe; Scottish Trade; the Darien Scheme; the Famine; Scottish Banking; the Union of 1707; Daniel Defoe; the 1708 Invasion; the 1715 Uprising; Glasgow’s Story; General Wade; Porteous Riots; Robert Walpole; Bonnie Prince Charlie and the ‘Forty Five; the Hanoverians; Culloden; Stirling’s Story; the Rule of the Church; the Enlightenment; the Golden Age; Edinburgh’s Story; Robert Adam; Church Schisms; Law and Order; Robert Burns; Scottish Medicine; the Industrial Revolution; Sea Traders.

Volume Four – 1784 to 2000: Rise of the Radicals; Music in Scotland; Militia Riots; Eastern Exiles; Aberdeen’s Story; Sir Walter Scott; Radical War; the Machine Age; the Railways; Irish Influx; the Highland Clearances; Social Unrest; the Disruption and Rise of the Free Church; the Orange Order; Scottish Soldiers; Age of Splendour; Robert Louis Stevenson; Queen Victoria; the Highland Protests; Publishing in Scotland; Artistic Revival; Ship Building and Industry; Rise of Socialism; Women’s Suffrage; the Second Enlightenment; Imperial Scots; the Great War; Industrial Unrest; Liberalism; Education; John Buchan; Economic Decline; Modernism; Sectarianism; Reconstruction; Second World War; the Churches; SNP and Nationalism; the Fishing Industry; North Sea Oil; Folk Revival; Devolution Thwarted; Immigration; Transport; Political Dissent; Nuclear Scotland; Devolution; Social Change; Scotland the Brand; Language; Innovation; the Future; Comprehensive Index.

item.title: Main Page Small Titles
item.dc:creator: boutje777
item.description: All sorts of comics that has no more than 5 issues on the page. Click on one of the titles which will lead you to the download- and informationpage for that comic (opens in a new window). You can close that window when you are finished and you will be back on this page for […]
item.content:encoded:
All sorts of comics that has no more than 5 issues on the page.

Click on one of the titles which will lead you to the download- and informationpage for that comic (opens in a new window).
You can close that window when you are finished and you will be back on this page for the other titles.

item.title: Main Page Pre60s
item.dc:creator: boutje777
item.description: All sorts of comics from mostly the period 1940-1960. Click on one of the titles which will lead you to the download- and informationpage for that comic (opens in a new window). You can close that window when you are finished and you will be back on this page for the other titles.
item.content:encoded:
All sorts of comics from mostly the period 1940-1960.

Click on one of the titles which will lead you to the download- and informationpage for that comic (opens in a new window).
You can close that window when you are finished and you will be back on this page for the other titles.
